//Source Activity Source Copyright policy
//About Activity MECHIE is a general purpose tool for mechanical engineers with information on concepts throughout multiple disciplines, physical constants, equations, and multiple tools such as a dimensionless number calculator and a hardness converter. All the information, data, equations, constants, calculations, etc presented in this application are to be used at the owner\'s discretion. The programmer is not liable nor responsible for any damages or losses incurred from using this information. It is expressly understood that the user understands the risk of continued use of this information in an \'as-is'\ basis. Much of the conceptual information contained in this application was comes from Wikipedia.com and its various sources, while most of the data (thermal coefficients, densities, numbers, etc) was sourced from Matweb.com and EngineeringToolbox.com.
//Copyleft Activity Use of the information presented in this app is subject to the following terms: MECHIE grants the user unlimited, personal use of any information presented in this app, including, but not limited to all images, equations, numbers, calculations, text, and other assets, as all information was collected from various open sources, be it offline or online databases.
//Moment of Inertia The moment of inertia, otherwise known as the angular mass or rotational inertia, of a rigid body is a tensor that determines the torque needed for a desired angular acceleration about a rotational axis; similar to how mass determines the force needed for a desired acceleration. It depends on the body\'s mass distribution and the axis chosen, with larger moments requiring more torque to change the body\'s rotation rate. It is an extensive (additive) property: for a point mass the moment of inertia is just the mass times the square of the perpendicular distance to the rotation axis. The moment of inertia of a rigid composite system is the sum of the moments of inertia of its component subsystems (all taken about the same axis). Its simplest definition is the second moment of mass with respect to distance from an axis. For bodies constrained to rotate in a plane, only their moment of inertia about an axis perpendicular to the plane, a scalar value, matters. For bodies free to rotate in three dimensions, their moments can be described by a symmetric 3 Ã— 3 matrix, with a set of mutually perpendicular principal axes for which this matrix is diagonal and torques around the axes act independently of each other. Moment of Inertia I is defined as the ratio of the net angular momentum L of a system to its angular velocity Ï‰ around a principle axis, that is If the angular momentum of a system is constant, then as the moment of inertia decreases, the angular velocity must increase. An example of this can be seen when spinning figure skaters pull in their outstretched arms, or divers curl their bodies into a tuck position during a dive, to spin faster. If the shape of the body does not change, then its moment of inertia appears in Newton\'s Law of Motion as the ratio of an applied torque Ï„ on a body to the angular acceleration Î± around a principle axis, that is For a simple pendulum, this definition yields a formula for the moment of inertia in terms of the mass m of the pendulum and its distance r from the pivot point as, Thus, moment of inertia depends on both the mass of a body and its geometry, or shape, as defined by the distance to the axis of rotation. This simple formula generalizes to define moment of inertia for an arbitrarily shaped body as the sum of all the elemental point masses dm each multiplied by the square of its perpendicular distance r to an axis k. In general, given an object of mass m, an effective radius k can be defined for an axis through its center of mass, with such a value that its moment of inertia is where k is known as the radius of gyration.
//Castigliano's Method Named after the Italian mathematician and physicist, Carlo Alberto Castigliano, Castigliano\'s Method describes a method to determine the deflections of beams. Determining the deflection of beams typically requires repeated integration of singularity functions and/or superposition, Castigliano\'s Method allows determination of deflection by using the strain energies located at the point of application of the forces on the beam. In addition, this method allows calculation of deflection of beams with changing cross-sectional areas. Note that the force mentioned in the two theorems below can refer to either a point force or a couple (moment), and the displacement can refer to either translation or angular rotation. The first partial derivative of the total internal energy (strain energy) in a structure with respect to any particular deflection component at a point is equal to the force applied at that point and in the direction corresponding to that deflection component. This theorem applies to both linearly and nonlinearly elastic structures in which the temperature is constants and the supports are not yielding. The first partial derivative of the total internal energy in a structure with respect to the force applied at any point is equal to the deflection at the point of application of that force in the direction of its line of action. This theorem applies only to linearly elastic structures with constant temperature and non-yielded supports. Given a thin, straight, cantilevered beam with a vertical load P at the end, the displacement Î´ can be found using Castigliano\'s Second Theorem: where E is the Modulus of Elasticity, I is the second moment of area of the cross-section, and M(x) = Px is the equation for the internal moment at a point that\'s x distance from the end, therefore: The resulting formula is the standard formula applicable only to cantilever beams under end loads.
//Galvanic Corrosion Galvanic corrosion (or bimetallic corrosion is an electrochemical process in which a metal corrodes when in electrical contact with another, in the presence of an electrolyte. When two dissimilar metals come in contact with an electrolyte, one metal acts at an anode while the other acts as a cathode. The electropotential difference between the two metals is the force driving the rate at which the anode dissolves into the electrolyte. The electropotential difference can be indicated by the relative positions of the two metals in the Galvanic Series. The Galvanic Series (or electropotential series) ranks the nobility of metals and semi-metals. Metals experience galvanic corrosion when submerged in an electrolyte while also connected to an external conductor. In terms of the Galvanic Series, it shows that the less noble of the two connected metals is the one to experience corrosion. In effect, the less noble metal has a lower electrode potential, and thus functions as the anode within the electrolyte device. One fantastic example of galvanic corrosion occurred in the Statue of Liberty in the 1980s, when a regular maintenance check revealed that corrosion had taken place between the outer copper skin and the wrought iron support structure. The problem had been anticipated when the statue was built, bu the insulation layer of shellac between the two metals (to prevent corrosion) had failed over time, resulting in rusting of the iron supports. A complete disassembly of the statue replaced the original insulation with polytetrafluoroethylene (PFTE). As an example, if zinc were in contact with silver and submerged in a salt-water solution, the zinc would corrode, as it is further down the list, thus more anodic, and thus will transfer ions to the silver.
